Bio-oil is a kind of viable renewable and environmentally sustainable energy, which is obtained from fast pyrolysis of biomass. However, bio-oil is not suitable for direct application due to the high content of oxygen and moisture. The upgrading of bio-oil, especially hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oil is highly demanded but remains a challenge owing to the absence of efficient and stable catalysts. Herein, an amphiphilic Pd/carbon-silica-alumina catalyst could catalytic reactions at the oil/water interface and simultaneously stabilized the oil/water emulsions, which would be highly advantageous in bio-oil upgrading. Significantly, the hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity of the catalyst could be adjusted by changing the input amount of precursor with resols, tetraethyl orthosilicate and aluminum chloride hexahydrate. In the catalytic reaction, phenol was used as a model bio-oil compound, where decalin and water were used to simulate an oil/water mixed bio-oil system. The as prepared amphipathic Pd/MCSA-24 catalyst showed the highest conversion of phenol (98.0%) and highest selectivity for cyclohexane (87.7%) at 200 °C, which presented great potential in further bio-oil upgrading applications. Graphical abstract A highly hydrodeoxygenation activity of bio-oil model compound phenol to fuels over Pd/Mesoporous C-SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Bio-oil upgrading Phenol Two-phase catalysis Hydrodeoxygenation Palladium 1 Introduction Bio-oil is considered as a promising transportation fuel, which derived from pyrolysis of biomass [1–3]. However, bio-oil has undesirable characteristics as an oil/water mixed system and high oxygen content [4,5]. Therefore, it must be subjected to hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) refining before being directly used as fuel [6–12]. Catalysts play a critical role in the HDO reaction of bio-oil upgrading. Unfortunately, the high oxygen values of bio-oil cause rapid catalyst deactivation using sulphide Co(Ni)-Mo catalysts [13–15]. In addition, the originally sulphur-free bio-oil and the products may be contaminated by sulphur [7,16]. Noble metal catalysts, such as Pd, Ru, Rh, and Pt were also known to be good candidates and to have HDO activity with low oxygen content and a high H/C ratio [17–22]. Support is another key factor determining the HDO activity of catalysts. Commonly employed supports include Al2O3, SiO2, ZrO2, TiO2, activated carbon, HZSM-5, etc. [23–34]. These supports are either hydrophilic or hydrophobic, which is not suitable for applied to the oil/water emulsions in bio-oil systems. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a catalyst with amphiphilic characteristics. Crossley et al. [35] reported amphiphilic materials, i.e. carbon nanotube-inorganic oxide hybrid nanoparticles, which were selectively localised to the oil/water interface and shown catalytic activity in both phases [36]. However, carbon nanotubes are not good hydrophobic materials as they are expensive and with a low specific surface area. Therefore, it is necessary to synthesise cheaper supports with a larger specific surface area and suitable pore size. There has been a great deal of interest in ordered mesoporous nanocomposites with high surface area, diverse composition, well-controlled pore structure, and tuneable pore size that facilitate the diffusion of reactant and product inside the pores [37–40]. Hydrophobic mesoporous carbon-based nanocomposites are of particular interest due to their potential applications as catalyst supports [41]. Hydrophilic mesoporous alumina-silicates act as a solid acid catalysts with good hydrothermal stability [42,43]. It has been proposed that hydrophobisation with carbon would hinder direct contact of hot water and silica-alumina, thus preventing collapse of the framework during the reaction in hot liquid water. Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of alumina are beneficial for deoxygenation of bio-oil [44]. Mesoporous carbon-silica-alumina, having both hydrophilic and hydrophobic characteristics, is a very promising nanocomposite using as a support for HDO of bio-oil refinery. These materials have high affinity for liquid-liquid interfaces, with the remarkable property of stabilising emulsions with small droplet size. In addition, they can facilitate the separation of products by enhancement of the liquid-solid-liquid interfacial area [42]. Phenol derivatives are considered to be the most stable components of bio-oil [7,13,45]. Herein, we synthesized a range of ordered mesoporous Pd/carbon-silica-alumina to stabilise oil/water emulsion, and as a catalyst for HDO of the bio-oil model compound, phenol, at the oil/water interface. The mesoporous nanocomposites were produced based on a triblock copolymer templating approach, with large pore sizes and hybrid pore surfaces composed of carbon and silica-alumina. The most efficient way to promote reactions is to place the solid catalyst at the liquid/liquid interface and to maximise the extent of the interface by creating an emulsion. Herein, we adjusted the proportions of carbon and silica-alumina to place the solid Pd catalyst at the oil/water interface and exhibited outstanding catalytic activity in bio-oil upgrading. 2 Experiment material and methods 2.1 Chemicals Poly(ethylene oxide)-block-poly (propylene oxide)-block-poly (ethylene oxide) triblock copolymer Pluronic F127 (Mw = 12,600, PEO106PPO70PEO106) was purchased from Sigma Corp. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 99.9%), phenol (99.6%), formalin solution (37 wt%), PdCl2 (Pd 59% – 60%), decalin (99%), ethanol absolute (99.8%), dichloromethane (99.9%) and cyclohexanol (99%), cyclohexanone (99.9%) and cyclohexane (99.9%) were purchased from Aladdin Corp. AlCl3•6H2O (97%), sodium hydroxide (96%) and hydrochloric acid (36% – 38%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Ltd. Corp. All chemicals were used as received without any further purification. Deionised water was used in all experiments. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of resol precursors The resol precursor (Mw < 500) was prepared according to the method reported in the literature [46]. In a typical procedure, 20.0 g of phenol was melted at 40 – 42 °C in a flask and mixed with 4.3 g of 20 wt% NaOH aqueous solution with stirring. After 10 min, 35.4 g of formalin (37 wt% formaldehyde) was added dropwise below 50 °C. Upon further stirring for 1 h at 70 – 75 °C, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and the pH was adjusted to about 6.0 with HCl solution. After water was removed by vacuum evaporation below 50 °C, the final product was dissolved in ethanol (20 wt% ethanolic solution). 2.2.2 Synthesis of ordered mesoporous carbon-silica-alumina with different proportions of carbon and silica-alumina Ordered mesoporous carbon-silica-alumina was synthesised by a solvent evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method with triblock copolymer F127 as a template in ethanol solution. Mesoporous carbon-silica-alumina was prepared by co-assembly of resols, oligomer aluminates from AlCl3•6H2O, oligomer silicates from TEOS and triblock copolymer F127 template [37]. In a typical preparation, 2.0 g of block copolymer F127 was dissolved in 10.0 g of ethanol with 2.0 g of 0.2 M HCl and stirred for 1 h at 40 °C to afford a clear solution. Next, 4.16 g of TEOS, 0.22 g of AlCl3•6H2O and 1.6 g of 20 wt% resol ethanolic solution were added in sequence. After stirring for 2 h, the mixture was transferred into dishes. It took 5 – 8 h at room temperature to evaporate the ethanol and 24 h at 100 °C in an oven to thermo-polymerise. The as-made products, flaxen and transparent membranes, were scraped from the dishes and ground into fine powders. Calcination was carried out in a tubular furnace at 900 °C for 2 h under N2 flow to obtain mesoporous carbon-silica-alumina nanocomposite, the particle size of that was less than 7 nm, designated as MCSA-24. “MCSA-x” denotes the mesoporous carbon-silica-alumina nanocomposite samples, where x represents the percentage carbon compound content in the carbon-silica-alumina. The heating rate was 1 °C/min below 600 °C and 5 °C/min above 600 °C. 2.2.3 Preparation of supported catalysts Pd/MCSA-100, Pd/MCSA-42, Pd/MCSA-24, Pd/MCSA-16 and Pd/MCSA-0 The 3 wt% Pd-based catalysts supported on mesoporous carbon-silica-alumina were produced by incipient wetness impregnation with ethanol solution using the metal precursor (PdCl2). In a typical procedure [47], 0.05 g of PdCl2 was dissolved in ethanol and then impregnated with 1 g of dry carrier. The concentration of PdCl2 solution was 2.5 g/L, and the solution/support ratio was 20:1. After impregnation and drying in air at room temperature, the samples were further dried overnight at 110 °C, reduced at 200 °C in 10 vol% hydrogen in nitrogen for 3 h, the heating rate was 2 °C/min, the flow rate was 10 mL/min. It designated as fresh supported catalysts (Pd/MCSA-100, Pd/MCSA-42, Pd/MCSA-24, Pd/MCSA-16 and Pd/MCSA-0). The fresh reduced catalysts were stored in vacuum dryer. 2.3 Analytical methods Thermogravimetry (TGA) was conducted using an STA 449 F3 simultaneous thermal analyser (Netzsch Co.). The test conditions were from room temperature to 900 °C in air, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were taken on a PANalyticalX' Pert Pro diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA, λ = 0.15408 nm). The d spacing values were calculated by the formula d = λ/2sinθ, and the unit cell parameters were calculated from the formula a 0 = 2d 100/√3. The metallic Pd sizes were estimated according to the Scherrer formula (size = 0.89λ/βcosθ) based on the (111) diffraction peak in wide-angle XRD patterns. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K with a Quantanchrome NOVA l000eAnalyser. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface areas. The pore diameter (D) was determined from the desorption branch according to the Barrett–Joyner–Halanda (BJH) method. The total pore volume (Vt ) was estimated from the amount adsorbed at the relative pressure (P/P 0) of 0.99. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) experiments were conducted using a Tecnai G220S-TWIN microscope (FEI Co.) operated at 200 kV. The amount and strength of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites were measured by ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) curves using a homemade apparatus. Samples of 100 mg were pre-treated at 500 °C in argon (20 mL/min) for 2 h. After the sample had cooled down to 120 °C, the ammonia was injected as a pulse until the acid sites were saturated at 120 °C. Then, the sample was flushed with argon to remove the physically adsorbed NH3. Finally, desorption of NH3 was carried out from 120 °C to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of argon (20 mL/min). NH3-TPD signals were monitored online using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.4 Apparatus and experimental procedures The catalyst (0.5 g) was dispersed in a 30 mL mixture of equal volumes of decalin and deionized water, ultrasonicating as described above. The mixture was placed in a 200 mL stainless steel batch autoclave equipped with an electrical heating jacket and a mechanical stirrer. 30 mL of a mixture of equal volumes of decalin and deionized water containing the reaction was poured into the same reactor. The autoclave was pressurised at 5 MPa H2 (room temperature). Hydrotreatment reactions were conducted at 200 °C for 2 h with a stirring speed of 600 rpm and heating to 200 °C at a rate of 2 °C/min. After cooling to room temperature and separation of the decalin and aqueous phases, the aqueous products were extracted with dichloromethane. The organic and aqueous phases were analysed both qualitatively and quantitatively by gas chromatography-mass spectroscopy (GC–MS) (7890A/5975C, Agilent) and a gas chromatography-flame ionization detector (GC-FID) equipped with a capillary column (122-3232 DB-FFAP). The conversion of phenol (Yphenol) and product selectivity (Si) were defined as follows: (1) Y phenol = ( 1 − n phenol n phenol , 0 ) × 100 % (2) S i = ( 1 − n i n phenol , 0 − n phenol ) × 100 % where nphenol,0 and nphenol denote the molar concentrations of phenol in the feed and product, respectively, and ni is the molar concentration of product i (e.g. cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone). The composition of the gas phase was determined by GC using an instrument (HP 6890) equipped with a plot Q capillary column with a TCD. We found 99% hydrogen and trace amounts of CO2 in the gas phase, so only changes in the liquid phase were considered in this study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 Carbon content crystal analysis The carbon content of C-SiO2-Al2O3 support was conducted by thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), as shown in Fig. 1 a and b. The material CSA-16 showed a decrease in mass at temperature of about 100 °C and the weight loss of 2.2%. An initial temperature of carbon combustion at which loss of mass occurs, Ti, of about 546 °C, and a temperature at which loss of mass ceases, Tf, of about 641 °C, and the weight loss of 16%. According to the TG formula, the material has carbon contents of 16%. Therefore, the material was designated as MCSA-16. Corresponding to the differential thermal curve of Fig. 1a, there is a more pronounced endothermic peak at around of 100 °C and an exothermic peak in the temperature from 546 °C – 641 °C. The carbon combustion zones (Ti – Tf) of these materials were similar. The weight loss of these materials was 24% and 42%. According to the TG formula, these supports have carbon contents of 24% and 42%, respectively. Therefore, these materials were designated as MCSA-24, and MCSA-42, respectively. TGA and DSC curves indicated that these materials showed a decrease in mass at temperatures of about 100 °C, and the weight loss was decreasing with the increase of the resol precursors amount, and the endothermic peak at the temperature of about 100 °C on the differential thermal curve was also decreasing. The weight loss material should be the water of adsorption by silicon hydroxyl. At the temperature of about 100 °C, the endothermic reaction of water took place to generate water vapour and overflow. This effect was especially obvious for MCSA-16. As these materials showed endothermic reactions with loss of water, the adsorption of heat by MCSA-16 was greater in this phase, thus confirming its higher water content. In the three materials, with the continuous decreasing in carbon content, the material exposed to the increasing of silicon hydroxyl, resulting in weight loss was increasing. The XRD patterns for fresh Pd/MCSA-16, Pd/MCSA-24 and Pd/MCSA-42 after reduction (Fig. 1c) showed two broad reflection peaks at 2θ of ~22°, which were assigned to amorphous carbon-silica-alumina for fresh mesoporous Pd/MCSA catalysts. Pd/MCSA-100 also showed broad reflection peaks at about 23° and 44° in the XRD pattern due to the amorphous carbon framework, and Pd/MCSA-0 showed a peak at about 22° corresponding to the amorphous silica-alumina framework. Four well-resolved diffraction peaks at 40.2°, 46.6°, 68.3° and 82.2° were observed in these catalysts, which were assigned to the 111, 200, 220 and 311 reflections of the face-centred cubic Pd lattice, respectively [48]. According to the Scherrer formula, the average crystallite sizes of the Pd/MCSA-100, Pd/MCSA-42, Pd/MCSA-24, Pd/MCSA-16 and Pd/MCSA-0 catalysts were estimated to be about 6.8 nm, 5.7 nm, 5.2 nm, 4.7 nm and 6.3 nm, respectively. No palladium oxide peak was observed, indicating that the present experimental conditions represented a useful method to synthesise high-purity palladium nanoparticles. The XPS data also supported the conclusion (Fig. S3). 3.1.2 Structural and morphology properties of catalysts Small-angle XRD diffraction patterns of these catalysts were shown in Fig. 2 a. Small-angle XRD patterns clearly showed three well-resolved diffraction peaks at 0.84°, 1.45° and 1.67°, with a ratio of 1/d of 1∶ √ 3 ∶2, which were attributed to the characteristic diffraction peaks of the 10, 11 and 20 reflection of highly ordered two-dimensional (2-D) hexagonal symmetry with space group p6mm, indicating a highly ordered meso-structure [49,50]. Notably, all unit parameters a0 were much larger than that of carbon, indicating that the incorporation of rigid inorganic silica-alumina efficiently reduced framework shrinkage in comparison to pure carbon. Pd/MCSA-24 had the maximum a0. When silica-alumina content was over 76%, the a0 decreased. TEM images of catalysts Pd/MCSA-100 (Fig. 2b) and Pd/MCSA-24 (Fig. 2c) showed a typical strip-type pattern with a 2-D hexagonal meso‑structure [50]. The channel spacing of the Pd/MCSA-100 was about 4 nm and the pore spacing of the Pd/MCSA-24 was about 5 nm. The channel spacing of Pd/MCSA-24 was wider than that of Pd/MCSA-100. The incorporation of inorganic silica-alumina into the carbon framework could reduce channel shrinkage during calcination of these mesoporous materials. The relatively larger channels of Pd/MCSA-24 were more conducive to loading of the active components. The small black spots seen in the TEM images were palladium nanoparticles. In Pd/MCSA-100, the average particle size for Pd particles was about 7 nm, while that in Pd/MCSA-24 was about 5 nm in diameter. These Pd nanoparticles were dispersed within the channels of Pd/MCSA-100 and Pd/MCSA-24, with no obvious aggregation. 3.1.3 Physicochemical properties characterisation The N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of these catalysts with different carbon contents are shown in Fig. 3 a and b. The catalysts Pd/MCSA-24 and Pd/MCSA-16 exhibited type-IV N2 sorption isotherms with distinct capillary condensation steps at relative pressures of 0.5 – 0.7 and an H1-type hysteresis loop, suggesting a narrow mesopore size distribution with cylindrical channels [51,52]. These observations were consistent with highly ordered meso-structure, confirmed by the TEM and small-angle XRD results. From the adsorption branch based on the BJH model, the mean pore size diameters of Pd/MCSA-24 and Pd/MCSA-16 were 4.9 nm and 4.3 nm, respectively, and were larger than those of Pd/MCSA-100. These observations indicated that the incorporation of inorganic silica-alumina could efficiently reduce framework shrinkage when the catalysts were calcinated. Based on the BJH model, Pd/MCSA-24 and Pd/MCSA-16 had specific surface areas of 275 m2/g and 206 m2/g, respectively. The catalysts Pd/MCSA-100 and Pd/MCSA-42 also exhibited type-IV isotherms with capillary condensation at relative pressure of 0.4 – 0.6, but an H2-type hysteresis loop. These observations indicated that these materials do not have symmetrical cylindrical pores, and therefore the surfaces of Pd/MCSA-100 and Pd/MCSA-42 channels would be rough due to asymmetric contraction of the framework during calcination. The capillary condensation occurs at lower P/P0, indicating the small size of the channels in these catalysts (the average pore diameters of Pd/MCSA-100 and Pd/MCSA-42 were 3.4 nm and 3.6 nm, respectively), consistent with the framework shrinkage of the materials. Pd/MCSA-100 and Pd/MCSA-42 had specific surface areas and pore volumes of 456 m2/g and 0.30 cm3/g and 337 m2/g and 0.30 cm3/g, respectively. The catalyst Pd/MCSA-0 exhibited mesoporous molecular sieve type-IV isotherms with capillary condensation at a relative pressure of 0.4 – 1.0 and an H1-type hysteresis loop. This was consistent with a highly ordered meso-structure. The average pore size, specific surface area, and pore volume were 5.6 nm, 494 m2/g and 0.65 cm3/g, respectively. Thus, the pore size of Pd/MCSA-0 was uniform and large. Ammonia thermo-programmed desorption curves of the samples are shown in Fig. 3c. These catalysts, Pd/MCSA-0, Pd/MCSA-16, Pd/MCSA-24 and Pd/MCSA-42, were all acid supports have two distinct ammonia desorption peaks. The ammonia desorption peak at 210 °C was ascribed to the weakly bonded ammonia adsorbed, suggesting that theses catalysts possess abundant weak acid sites. The other desorption peak was observed at 420 °C, corresponding to strong acid sites also implying that they had abundant strong acid sites. As shown in Fig. S1, these catalysts are rich in the Lewis acid sites. In addition, the intensity of the band clearly increased with decreasing carbon content. In addition, corresponding pore characteristics, including crystal cell parameters, BET surface area, pore diameter and pore volumes were summarised in Table 1 . The acidities of these supports were calculated from the peak areas, as summarised in Table 2 . The weak acid, strong acid and total acid contents of these supports decreased monotonically with increasing carbon content. It did not change the strengths of the acid sites, but the amounts of acid could be changed by adjusting the proportions of hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity of the materials. This can be explained as the acidity of the supports being mainly due to the Al2O3 surface, and by the acid content of the catalyst being related to the silica-alumina content. This could also be deduced from the decrease in surface area of silica-alumina with increasing carbon content. The active sites of alumina were covered, and the direct contact of Al2O3 and oxygen was hindered by the inclusion of more carbon. Therefore, the acid content of catalysts was reduced. The NH3-TPD curve of mesoporous carbon showed no peaks, indicating that mesoporous carbon had no acidity (Table 2). 3.2 Catalytic performances 3.2.1 Catalytic performance on different catalysts in the single aqueous phase and two-phase systems The optimize reaction conditions with temperature and H2 pressure have been investigated in the Table S1 and Table S2. The optimum reaction temperature is 200 °C and the H2 pressure is 5 MPa. The mesoporous Pd/MCSA catalyst was tested on the HDO reaction of phenol, in the single aqueous phase and two-phase systems, at 200 °C under hydrogen at a pressure of 5 MPa as shown in Table 3 . It could be noted that with different hydrophilic, hydrophobic, and amphipathic catalysts, the phenol conversion was higher in the biphasic system than in the single aqueous phase. The phenol conversion with amphipathic catalyst after 2 h of reaction was ~59.7% in single aqueous phase and 98.0% in biphasic (emulsion) system with corresponding increase in yield of cyclohexane, which proves the higher efficacy of the biphasic system, probably due to the increase in the interfacial area. Moreover, the amphipathic catalyst exhibited a much higher activity than the hydrophilic and hydrophobic catalysts. For example, in the 2 h reaction in the biphasic system, the conversion of phenol was only 74.1% with the hydrophilic catalyst, but 98.0% for the amphipathic catalyst. The higher activity of amphipathic catalyst to be served in the biphasic system could be ascribed to dispersal of Pd on the polar carbon and silica-alumina, as well as to increased exposure of the catalyst at the interface. This enhancement could also be ascribed to maximised particle dispersion and enhanced hydrogen concentration at the interface. 3.2.2 Effects of carbon/(silica-alumina) of Pd/C-SiO2-Al2O3 on hydrodeoxygenation of phenol at the oil/water interface Carbon could produce water-in-oil emulsions, because its hydrophobicity preferentially orients it toward the oil phase at the interface. Silica-alumina could produce emulsions, but only in the oil-in-water system due to its hydrophilicity. An amphipathic nanoparticle as MCSA carrier had been prepared. By tuning the proportion of carbon and silica-alumina, we could modify the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance and assemble oil-in-water or water-in-oil emulsions (Fig. S2, S6). The different proportions of hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity of Pd/MCSA catalysts markedly influenced the catalytic activity. Pd/MCSA-24 showed a higher conversion of phenol (98.0%) and greater selectivity for cyclohexane (87.7%) than Pd/MCSA-16 and Pd/MCSA-42. Pd/MCSA-42 showed a higher phenol conversion (87.4%) than Pd/MCSA-16 (80.4%) (Table 4 ). As Pd/MCSA-16 is more hydrophilic than Pd/MCSA-24, while Pd/MCSA-42 is more hydrophobic than Pd/MCSA-24 (Fig. S3), they cannot be entirely distributed at the oil/water interface. The selectivity for cyclohexane was higher with Pd/MCSA-16 (81.5%) than Pd/MCSA-42 (73.9%) (Table 4), and therefore Pd/MCSA-16 had higher deoxygenation activity. Fig. 4 A compared the time evolution of conversion for the different hydrophilic, hydrophobic, and amphipathic catalysts. A clear difference was observed among the three hydrophilic, hydrophobic, and amphipathic catalysts. While the amphipathic catalyst showed a continuous increase in the phenol conversion with the reaction time. For instance, while conversion on the amphiphilic catalyst from 0.5 h to 2 h of reaction goes from 45% to 99%, nearly no change in conversion was observed with the hydrophilic and hydrophobic catalysts after 1.5 h. That means the hydrophilic, hydrophobic catalyst was nearly deactivated at this point. Fig. 4B showed the time evolution of the selectivity of products during the reaction of HDO of phenol in the emulsion systems at 200 °C and 5 MPa of H2 over amphiphilic catalyst Pd/MCSA-24. It was observed that with the increase of reaction time, the selectivity of cyclohexane was gradually increasing and the selectivity of cyclohexanol was gradually decreased. This indicating that the reaction mechanism was firstly hydrogenation to produce cyclohexanol, then cyclohexanol dehydrated to form cyclohexene, and cyclohexene was unstable and rapidly hydrogenated to form cyclohexane. 3.2.3 Catalyst regenerability and reusability of the catalysts To evaluate the potential regenerability and reusability, the hydrothermal stabilities of Pd/MCSA-24 and Pd/MCSA-0 were tested by evaluating their catalytic activities as shown in Table 5 , with maintenance of the reaction conditions as described above except using recovered catalysts. First, the HDO reaction of phenol was run for 2 h in the batch reactor as described above. After the first reaction period, the catalyst was separated from the resulting liquid by centrifugation at 6000 rpm for 20 min. then the catalyst was washed with water, then with decalin, and finally centrifuged again to separate it from the liquid followed by drying overnight in air at 110 °C. In order to overcome the lost during the separation, washing, and drying process, the catalysts of two runs were combined in order to load the same amount of catalyst in the reactor for the second reaction run. The comparison of activity between the first run, the second run and the third run with the two catalysts were made in Table 5. A remarkable difference was observed. While the Pd/MCSA-24 was seen to retain a large fraction of its original activity (~84%) after second time reused, indicating that the catalyst Pd/MCSA-24 was stable. The selectivity of target product cyclohexane was remained almost the same. It is clearly observed that the activity was decreased, especially after third time reused. The results, however, were far superior to those of catalyst Pd/MCSA-0. The conversion of phenol decreased by 76% when the catalyst Pd/MCSA-0 was reused second times, the Pd/MCSA-0 had completely lost its activity after the third run, indicating the low hydrothermal stability of this catalyst. These observations could be the crystalline structure of MCSA-0 collapsed within a few hours of contact with hot liquid medium, resulting in the leaching of active particles and a lack of active sites, as shown in table S3. There is an important difference in the resistance to morphological deterioration that occurs in the liquid phase reaction at high temperature. As shown in Fig. 5 a, there was nearly no changes in the small-angle XRD of the used amphipathic Pd/MCSA-24, which indicated that the mesoporous structure of the amphipathic material remains largely undisrupted after exposure to the hot liquid at high temperature. By contrast, there was no obvious diffraction peak of the used hydrophilic Pd/MCSA-0 catalyst. These results showed that the ordered meso-structure of the catalyst was destroyed during the reaction. The contrasting behaviour of amphiphilic catalyst Pd/MCSA-24 compared to the Pd/MCSA-0 was clearer from the TEM images obtain after the reaction (Fig. 5b and c). The mesoporous structure of the Pd/MCSA-24 remains unchanged after reaction, while there were no observable ordered channels in the used Pd/MCSA-0. That means the mesoporous structure was collapsed in the liquid phase reaction at high temperature. 3.2.4 Hydrodeoxygenation reactions of phenol at the oil/water interface with amphipathic mesoporous Pd/carbon-silica-alumina The route for HDO of phenol over reduced metal catalysts could be described clearly by a kinetic model involving a two-step reaction, in which phenol was initially hydrogenated to cyclohexanol and then deoxygenated to cyclohexane (Fig. 6 ). In the catalyst Pd/C-SiO2-Al2O3, Pd nanoparticles are simultaneously supported on the hydrophobic mesoporous carbon and the hydrophilic silica-alumina, and the catalyst is distributed at the oil/water interface. The active hydrogen molecules at the oil/water interface and benzene ring undergo electrophilic addition reaction to produce cyclohexanone. The cyclohexanone in the water phase is transferred to the organic phase due to the difference in solubility and undergoes further hydrogenation to produce cyclohexanol. Due to the difference in solubility, cyclohexanol in the organic phase is transferred to the aqueous phase, and alcoholic hydroxyl undergoes a further deoxygenation reaction on the surface acid sites of the silica-alumina to produce cyclohexane. Cyclohexane is almost insoluble in the water phase. The transfer of large numbers of target products to the oil phase allows the forward reaction to occur. The catalytic reaction at the oil/water interface due to the occurrence of phase transfer can greatly improve the reaction rate. 4 Conclusions Heterogeneous palladium catalysts have been supported on ordered mesoporous hybrid carbon-silica-alumina materials, which were synthesised for the bio-oil model compound refinery. The heterogeneous amphipathic Pd/MCSA-24 catalyst showed the highest conversion of phenol (98.0%) and highest selectivity for cyclohexane (87.7%). The high catalytic performance of Pd/MCSA can be attributed to the hybrid pore surface being composed of hydrophilic silica-alumina and hydrophobic carbon, which can simultaneously catalyse reactants dissolved in water or decalin with a high specific surface area, large pore size, uniform dispersion of palladium, and relatively small Pd particle size. The optimal hydrophobicity/hydrophilicity ratio of a catalyst could be achieved with maximum distribution at the oil/water interface and stabilised emulsion, such as Pd/MCSA-24, thus allowing simultaneous two-phase catalytic reactions. The use of a mesoporous carbon-silica-alumina carrier provides an effective, mild, environmentally friendly route for HDO of phenol. This type of catalyst has huge advantages for catalysing interface reactions between two liquid phases. coredata.dc:description: Bio-oil is a kind of viable renewable and environmentally sustainable energy, which is obtained from fast pyrolysis of biomass. However, bio-oil is not suitable for direct application due to the high content of oxygen and moisture. The upgrading of bio-oil, especially hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oil is highly demanded but remains a challenge owing to the absence of efficient and stable catalysts. Herein, an amphiphilic Pd/carbon-silica-alumina catalyst could catalytic reactions at the oil/water interface and simultaneously stabilized the oil/water emulsions, which would be highly advantageous in bio-oil upgrading. Significantly, the hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity of the catalyst could be adjusted by changing the input amount of precursor with resols, tetraethyl orthosilicate and aluminum chloride hexahydrate. In the catalytic reaction, phenol was used as a model bio-oil compound, where decalin and water were used to simulate an oil/water mixed bio-oil system. The as prepared amphipathic Pd/MCSA-24 catalyst showed the highest conversion of phenol (98.0%) and highest selectivity for cyclohexane (87.7%) at 200 °C, which presented great potential in further bio-oil upgrading applications.
coredata.dc:title: An efficient Pd/carbon-silica-alumina catalyst for the hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oil model compound phenol
